div.ab:
ὑπατείαςὑπατίας τοῦ δεσπότου ἡμῶν Ὁνορίου
τοῦ αἰωνίου ΑὐγούστουἈγούστου τὸ ια καὶ Φλαουίου
Κωνσταντίου, λαμπρΚωσταντίου τοῦ λαµπροτάτου πατρικίου month day
ὁµολογεῖ Αὐρήλιος Ἰσι
ἐλαιουργόςαιλεουργω

item.p: On the consulship of Honorius and Fl. Constantius, see CLRE 368–9 and CSBE2 194, to which add the recently published P.Oxy. LXXII 4904.1–2 (7.xii.417). The consular dating is also attested in a Jewish marriage contract from Antinoopolis, where the Greek formula is transcribed in Aramaic letters; see Pap.Colon. XII.1–3 (15.xi.417). Two papyri from the following year (418), P.Köln II 102.1 (Oxy.) and CPR X 111.1 (Heracl.), are dated by the post-consulate of Honorius and Constantius. P.Vind. Sijp. 9.19–22 (Heracl.) has a garbled post-consulate date erroneously combining the consulship of Fl. Constantius with the seventh consulship of the emperor Theodosius II (= 416) and with an erratic indiction number; see CLRE 669. The post-consular dating by the consuls of 416 (Theodosius Aug. VII and Fl. Palladius) continues to figure in the papyri until mid-June of 417 (P.Berl. Zill. 5.1 [Herm.]), so we may presume our papyrus to date from the second half of the year (cf. 3 n.).

[Φλαουίου] Κωσταντίου (l. Κωνσταντίου) On Flavius Constantius, see PLRE II 321–5 s.v. ‘Fl. Constantius 17’. He was consul in the West also in 414 and 420. His second consulship coincided with his marriage to Honorius’ sister Placidia after her recovery from the Visigoths in the previous year, thanks in large part to Constantius’ own efforts; cf. Olympiodorus fr. 33.1 in R.C. Brockley, The Fragmentary Classicising Historians of the Later Roman Empire II (Liverpool 1983) 33.

Fl. Constantius was patricius from 415 until he was ephemerally proclaimed Augustus in 421 (he died in the same year); see PLRE II 323. The title, however, is only seldom recorded in dating formulas, the only other certain instances being Pap.Colon. XII.3 (in Aramaic transcription) and P.Oxy. VIII 1134.2 (421); see CSBE2 194 for other doubtful instances from 421. It is theoretically not impossible that π[ represents the month Π[αχων or Π[αυνι, but this is rendered very unlikely by the fact that the latest post-consular dating by the previous year’s consuls is from 21 Pauni = 15 June (see 1–3 n.); it is indeed very rare for the names of new consuls to be disseminated as early as June in fifth-century Egypt (see CSBE2 93). There probably would not be sufficient space for the restoration of the iteration numeral τὸ β after π[ατρικίου. The number is present only in P.Oxy. 4904.2. The two papyri dated by the post-consulate of Honorius and Constantius (see 1–3 n.) do not specify that this is Constantius’ second time as consul (this is not completely certain for CPR X 111.3; see the editor’s note), nor does Pap.Colon. XII according to its editors (pp. 26–7).

The last trace is compatible with sigma. Reading a dative form (ἐλαιουργῷ) would suggest a reference to the profession of the second party, but the preceding space is too short to include the names and patronymics of both parties.
